title: 古斯塔沃·杜达梅尔指挥施特劳斯与巴伯作品
short_description: 理查·施特劳斯与柏林爱乐乐团有着非常密切的关系，这位作曲家本人曾在数年间作为客席指挥执棒柏林爱乐乐团的演出。在这段视频中，古斯塔沃·杜达梅尔为我们演绎了两部施特劳斯的音诗《唐璜》和《蒂尔的恶作剧》以及塞缪尔·巴伯的哀伤之作《弦乐的柔板》。

interview.description: 2013年2月，委内瑞拉指挥家古斯塔沃·杜达梅尔指挥柏林爱乐乐团演绎了理查·施特劳斯的作品。在这段视频中，他于乐团的圆号演奏家莎拉·维利斯进行了一次对话。
interview.short_description: 2013年2月，委内瑞拉指挥家古斯塔沃·杜达梅尔指挥柏林爱乐乐团演绎了理查·施特劳斯的作品。在这段视频中，他于乐团的圆号演奏家莎拉·维利斯进行了一次对话。
interview.caption:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:00,810

2
00:00:00,810 --> 00:00:03,390
Maestro Gustavo Dudamel,
welcome back to the

3
00:00:03,390 --> 00:00:04,190
Philharmonie.

4
00:00:04,190 --> 00:00:05,200
Welcome back.

5
00:00:05,200 --> 00:00:07,640
Its your seventh time in
almost five years.

6
00:00:07,640 --> 00:00:08,920
That's really quite
incredible.

7
00:00:08,920 --> 00:00:09,970
Yes, yes.

8
00:00:09,970 --> 00:00:12,760
And it's a huge pleasure
and honor,

9
00:00:12,760 --> 00:00:14,340
always, to be back here.

10
00:00:14,340 --> 00:00:15,080
For us.

11
00:00:15,080 --> 00:00:15,550
For us.

12
00:00:15,550 --> 00:00:15,970
For us.

13
00:00:15,970 --> 00:00:18,240
But we are sitting in
the audience today.

14
00:00:18,240 --> 00:00:20,520
Usually we do the interviews on
stage, or in another room.

15
00:00:20,520 --> 00:00:22,000
Today I thought we'd sit
in the audience.

16
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:25,070
And I wanted to ask you, can you
remember the last time you

17
00:00:25,070 --> 00:00:26,320
sat in the audience here?

18
00:00:26,320 --> 00:00:28,830

19
00:00:28,830 --> 00:00:36,900
Last time I think was when you
were doing Carmen with Simon.

20
00:00:36,900 --> 00:00:38,420
I think this was last year.

21
00:00:38,420 --> 00:00:39,132
It was last year.

22
00:00:39,132 --> 00:00:41,100
So it's not that long ago.

23
00:00:41,100 --> 00:00:42,410
And I was listening there.

24
00:00:42,410 --> 00:00:45,460
Do you remember the
first time?

25
00:00:45,460 --> 00:00:51,160
The first time I came here
to conduct the Venezuelan

26
00:00:51,160 --> 00:00:54,280
National Children's Orchestra.

27
00:00:54,280 --> 00:00:56,910
And I remember, you were around,
and you let us to

28
00:00:56,910 --> 00:00:59,150
come, few musicians
of the orchestra.

29
00:00:59,150 --> 00:01:04,060
This was, I think, a rehearsal
of Bruckner Nine.

30
00:01:04,060 --> 00:01:08,460
And then I came to a concert
when I came here to study for

31
00:01:08,460 --> 00:01:09,710
three months.

32
00:01:09,710 --> 00:01:11,700

33
00:01:11,700 --> 00:01:15,270
It was a Haitink concert.

34
00:01:15,270 --> 00:01:17,060
Brahms Fourth.

35
00:01:17,060 --> 00:01:18,150
You've got a great memory.

36
00:01:18,150 --> 00:01:18,480
Yes.

37
00:01:18,480 --> 00:01:20,490
He was doing Brahms Four.

38
00:01:20,490 --> 00:01:23,230
And I think a special
composer.

39
00:01:23,230 --> 00:01:26,620
He was doing a symphony for
strings, I remember.

40
00:01:26,620 --> 00:01:29,730
Did you get to sit in such a
nice, expensive seat like this

41
00:01:29,730 --> 00:01:31,220
one, or were you standing
up in the back?

42
00:01:31,220 --> 00:01:31,760
No, no, no.

43
00:01:31,760 --> 00:01:32,980
I got good tickets.

44
00:01:32,980 --> 00:01:34,120
You got good tickets?

45
00:01:34,120 --> 00:01:34,750
Yes, I got good tickets.

46
00:01:34,750 --> 00:01:39,330
Because that day, I was arising
from Venezuela for

47
00:01:39,330 --> 00:01:45,310
this experience, to assist
Simon, to prepare the Academy

48
00:01:45,310 --> 00:01:48,040
orchestra, I was living
in this place.

49
00:01:48,040 --> 00:01:49,030
You were here for three months,

50
00:01:49,030 --> 00:01:50,040
and you were literally.

51
00:01:50,040 --> 00:01:50,880
I remember you.

52
00:01:50,880 --> 00:01:52,650
You were everywhere.

53
00:01:52,650 --> 00:01:54,690
Doesn't matter what time of
the morning or the night.

54
00:01:54,690 --> 00:01:55,250
I was here.

55
00:01:55,250 --> 00:01:56,310
You were always here.

56
00:01:56,310 --> 00:01:56,800
I was, all the time.

57
00:01:56,800 --> 00:01:59,530
And I remember, I was sleeping
there on the top.

58
00:01:59,530 --> 00:02:00,382
Up there in the box?

59
00:02:00,382 --> 00:02:01,400
Deliciously.

60
00:02:01,400 --> 00:02:02,550
I have--

61
00:02:02,550 --> 00:02:04,250
During rehearsals, I hope not.

62
00:02:04,250 --> 00:02:04,580
No.

63
00:02:04,580 --> 00:02:07,700
Not during rehearsals, but
between rehearsals.

64
00:02:07,700 --> 00:02:13,320
Because I was living in the
house of a Venezuelan friend,

65
00:02:13,320 --> 00:02:15,140
Thomas Clamor.

66
00:02:15,140 --> 00:02:17,100
I was living in his house.

67
00:02:17,100 --> 00:02:18,620
That was really fun.

68
00:02:18,620 --> 00:02:22,000
But they live very far, and it
was very expensive for me.

69
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:26,480
So I was sleeping here,
eating all the time--

70
00:02:26,480 --> 00:02:27,590
I remember you were there.

71
00:02:27,590 --> 00:02:28,580
--in the cafeteria.

72
00:02:28,580 --> 00:02:34,850
And for me, it's like a house.

73
00:02:34,850 --> 00:02:35,510
It's like home.

74
00:02:35,510 --> 00:02:39,670
Because I feel like I know every
corner of this place.

75
00:02:39,670 --> 00:02:42,990
And I was listening to concerts
there at the top.

76
00:02:42,990 --> 00:02:45,840
Sometimes I got great
invitation, I would say.

77
00:02:45,840 --> 00:02:47,090
And I was sitting here.

78
00:02:47,090 --> 00:02:50,260

79
00:02:50,260 --> 00:02:54,350
It's a beautiful part
of my life.

80
00:02:54,350 --> 00:02:58,360
Three months is a long time to
stay in one place here in the

81
00:02:58,360 --> 00:03:01,150
Philharmonie for you, because
you were otherwise traveling

82
00:03:01,150 --> 00:03:01,810
everywhere.

83
00:03:01,810 --> 00:03:04,290
What did those three months
bring to you, do you think?

84
00:03:04,290 --> 00:03:08,740

85
00:03:08,740 --> 00:03:13,510
Well, as you know, I did all
my musical education in

86
00:03:13,510 --> 00:03:16,290
Venezuela, in El Sistema.

87
00:03:16,290 --> 00:03:22,470
And Maestro Abreu and all my
teachers were the basis of all

88
00:03:22,470 --> 00:03:24,280
what I know about music.

89
00:03:24,280 --> 00:03:33,400
But to come here was my first,
let's say, international

90
00:03:33,400 --> 00:03:36,510
out-of-home experience.

91
00:03:36,510 --> 00:03:37,690
And it was great.

92
00:03:37,690 --> 00:03:43,790
Because we grew up listening and
watching concerts of the

93
00:03:43,790 --> 00:03:46,830
Berlin Philharmonic, especially
with Karajan.

94
00:03:46,830 --> 00:03:49,170
We were playing, for example,
Tchaikovsky

95
00:03:49,170 --> 00:03:51,240
Four a lot of times.

96
00:03:51,240 --> 00:03:53,520
Preparing that as a children's
orchestra.

97
00:03:53,520 --> 00:03:56,360
And which was the video
that we were watching?

98
00:03:56,360 --> 00:03:58,650
The video of Karajan with
the Berlin Philharmonic.

99
00:03:58,650 --> 00:04:02,670
So the reference was always
there, and we had this sound.

100
00:04:02,670 --> 00:04:07,840
But when you come here, it's
different, because it's real.

101
00:04:07,840 --> 00:04:12,580
And for me, I can say it changed
my life completely.

102
00:04:12,580 --> 00:04:17,209
Because the approach to the
music, the sound, the way to

103
00:04:17,209 --> 00:04:23,530
make the sound, gave me a
different dimension of how to

104
00:04:23,530 --> 00:04:26,630
think about what I want to
get from the orchestra.

105
00:04:26,630 --> 00:04:30,440
Because I was sitting here
listening, watching rehearsals

106
00:04:30,440 --> 00:04:36,600
of Haitink, Barenboim, Rattle,
Abbado, Ozawa--

107
00:04:36,600 --> 00:04:37,640
It's a dream for a
young conductor.

108
00:04:37,640 --> 00:04:37,910
--was at that time.

109
00:04:37,910 --> 00:04:42,280
I was like, wow, in
every rehearsal.

110
00:04:42,280 --> 00:04:45,130
And it was a luxury for me.

111
00:04:45,130 --> 00:04:47,760
Because you cannot come to a
first rehearsal, because you

112
00:04:47,760 --> 00:04:49,140
know-- and that is amazing.

113
00:04:49,140 --> 00:04:50,730
But I was allowed.

114
00:04:50,730 --> 00:04:54,280
And I was the only one here
listening, the first rehearsal

115
00:04:54,280 --> 00:04:55,300
of the Berlin Philharmonic,
in all the world.

116
00:04:55,300 --> 00:04:58,198
We were playing just for you.

117
00:04:58,198 --> 00:05:02,330
I was feeling like, oh, God,
I'm the owner of the world.

118
00:05:02,330 --> 00:05:03,290
Must have been absolute

119
00:05:03,290 --> 00:05:04,820
paradise for a young conductor.

120
00:05:04,820 --> 00:05:09,940
But that is what I recommend
to young conductors.

121
00:05:09,940 --> 00:05:13,160
Because they always come,
and they ask what to do.

122
00:05:13,160 --> 00:05:17,450
An I say, well, it's not a
better school than to go and

123
00:05:17,450 --> 00:05:20,750
to sit in a rehearsal
of a big conductor.

124
00:05:20,750 --> 00:05:25,990
And if you have the chance to be
here in Berlin, and to have

125
00:05:25,990 --> 00:05:29,145
the chance to see,
and to listen.

126
00:05:29,145 --> 00:05:33,360
Especially when you close
your eyes, you get a

127
00:05:33,360 --> 00:05:35,330
different kind of energy.

128
00:05:35,330 --> 00:05:38,640
The sound, especially, of the
Berlin Philharmonic is coming

129
00:05:38,640 --> 00:05:40,660
from the earth.

130
00:05:40,660 --> 00:05:42,110
I feel that all the time.

131
00:05:42,110 --> 00:05:45,460
It's not something like,
"ah!" it's [LOW GROWL].

132
00:05:45,460 --> 00:05:46,460
And that is great.

133
00:05:46,460 --> 00:05:47,800
It's another kind of approach.

134
00:05:47,800 --> 00:05:49,670
You grew up with the Berlin
Philharmonic.

135
00:05:49,670 --> 00:05:51,290
Because everybody knows
the story about you

136
00:05:51,290 --> 00:05:52,940
conducting your toys.

137
00:05:52,940 --> 00:05:56,040
You used to line up your toys
and conduct them to records of

138
00:05:56,040 --> 00:05:57,370
Berlin Phil, Vienna Phil.

139
00:05:57,370 --> 00:06:00,290
So you grew up with this
sound, the Berlin Phil.

140
00:06:00,290 --> 00:06:03,840
And you've done quite a few
programs now, but this is the

141
00:06:03,840 --> 00:06:07,960
first true German meat
that you're doing.

142
00:06:07,960 --> 00:06:14,130
Strauss is really one of our
basic repertoire things.

143
00:06:14,130 --> 00:06:17,540
I think the orchestra plays
Strauss really, really well.

144
00:06:17,540 --> 00:06:18,460
Do you?

145
00:06:18,460 --> 00:06:20,170
Well, let me tell you.

146
00:06:20,170 --> 00:06:24,390
When we did last year, the
Zarathustra, Also Sprach.

147
00:06:24,390 --> 00:06:27,540
And now we're doing
Don Juan and Till.

148
00:06:27,540 --> 00:06:32,120
But it was funny, because I was
checking some things in

149
00:06:32,120 --> 00:06:43,200
the string parts, and it said,
"Time of Dr. Strauss, 29

150
00:06:43,200 --> 00:06:47,600
minutes, or 30 minutes, in
very old-style letters.

151
00:06:47,600 --> 00:06:47,900
No!

152
00:06:47,900 --> 00:06:48,000
Yes.

153
00:06:48,000 --> 00:06:50,150
So this was the old music.

154
00:06:50,150 --> 00:06:51,970
And Strauss conducted here.

155
00:06:51,970 --> 00:06:54,310
He was 23 when he had his first

156
00:06:54,310 --> 00:06:55,185
debut here as a conductor.

157
00:06:55,185 --> 00:06:55,300
Incredible.

158
00:06:55,300 --> 00:06:55,920
Can you imagine that?

159
00:06:55,920 --> 00:06:56,380
No.

160
00:06:56,380 --> 00:06:56,740
Incredible.

161
00:06:56,740 --> 00:07:03,700
And this date was in
the '20s or '30s.

162
00:07:03,700 --> 00:07:07,350
Then it said Dr. Furtwangler,
this time.

163
00:07:07,350 --> 00:07:11,850
It's amazing, because you are
like, oh my God, it's history.

164
00:07:11,850 --> 00:07:13,170
It's tradition.

165
00:07:13,170 --> 00:07:15,740
It's really a tradition.

166
00:07:15,740 --> 00:07:17,620
Like, three days ago--

167
00:07:17,620 --> 00:07:20,120
four days ago, I was conducting
the Vienna

168
00:07:20,120 --> 00:07:21,140
Philharmonic.

169
00:07:21,140 --> 00:07:25,030
And we we're doing the
Siegfried-Idyll.

170
00:07:25,030 --> 00:07:29,950
Richter, that was the intendant
at that time, the

171
00:07:29,950 --> 00:07:34,530
very first one, he was the one
that prepared for Wagner the

172
00:07:34,530 --> 00:07:39,260
musicians to play for Cosima,
like a serenade.

173
00:07:39,260 --> 00:07:43,600
And it's funny, because I had
the score, I opened, and it

174
00:07:43,600 --> 00:07:48,870
has a paper that says, Richter
conducting, Richter, Strauss

175
00:07:48,870 --> 00:07:50,060
conducting--

176
00:07:50,060 --> 00:07:54,960
this kind of reference, when I
go here to the archives and I

177
00:07:54,960 --> 00:08:00,880
can see Karajan's, 'Boim,
Abbado, Furtwangler--

178
00:08:00,880 --> 00:08:04,000
you're talking about the
soul of this music.

179
00:08:04,000 --> 00:08:11,260
And this is a challenge, as a
young musician, to-- well,

180
00:08:11,260 --> 00:08:13,260
so-so, because I'm already 32.

181
00:08:13,260 --> 00:08:15,060
Yeah, you're getting on a bit.

182
00:08:15,060 --> 00:08:20,310
But when you come here,
you have to know

183
00:08:20,310 --> 00:08:21,240
what you want to get.

184
00:08:21,240 --> 00:08:23,080
Because of course, there
are not musicians

185
00:08:23,080 --> 00:08:26,710
here from that time.

186
00:08:26,710 --> 00:08:28,880
But they all learned from
the ones before.

187
00:08:28,880 --> 00:08:28,955
Exactly.

188
00:08:28,955 --> 00:08:30,130
It's the tradition.

189
00:08:30,130 --> 00:08:35,020
So you need to be really
well-prepared, very clear with

190
00:08:35,020 --> 00:08:39,850
your ideas, but also open to
receive what the orchestra is

191
00:08:39,850 --> 00:08:39,970
giving to you.

192
00:08:39,970 --> 00:08:41,120
Do you feel that tradition?

193
00:08:41,120 --> 00:08:41,610
Do you hear?

194
00:08:41,610 --> 00:08:43,890
Is that what you got on
stage, do you think?

195
00:08:43,890 --> 00:08:44,620
Absolutely.

196
00:08:44,620 --> 00:08:50,630
And you have in mind a tempo,
but that tempo change because

197
00:08:50,630 --> 00:08:54,380
the way to produce the sound
of the orchestra, and

198
00:08:54,380 --> 00:08:56,960
then you say, OK.

199
00:08:56,960 --> 00:08:57,940
This has to be like that.

200
00:08:57,940 --> 00:08:59,580
What is it that makes different
orchestras have

201
00:08:59,580 --> 00:09:02,280
these different souls,
do you think?

202
00:09:02,280 --> 00:09:08,070
Well, I think it's beautiful,
and has to be like that.

203
00:09:08,070 --> 00:09:13,170
Because if all the orchestras
played it in the same way, it

204
00:09:13,170 --> 00:09:15,460
would be really boring.

205
00:09:15,460 --> 00:09:22,510
And for us as conductors,
especially coming as a guest

206
00:09:22,510 --> 00:09:29,130
conductor, you try--

207
00:09:29,130 --> 00:09:31,200
it is my conception--

208
00:09:31,200 --> 00:09:37,130
I try to respect a lot what I
have from, of course, the

209
00:09:37,130 --> 00:09:42,430
musicians, and the way they
produce the sound.

210
00:09:42,430 --> 00:09:46,130
Because you can come in, you can
know about everything, and

211
00:09:46,130 --> 00:09:47,280
you are there.

212
00:09:47,280 --> 00:09:52,750
But you have to know that you
have to deal with this energy

213
00:09:52,750 --> 00:09:53,780
that is magic.

214
00:09:53,780 --> 00:09:57,700
Because it's not only to
move your hands in

215
00:09:57,700 --> 00:09:59,380
front of the orchestra.

216
00:09:59,380 --> 00:10:02,570
I think the musicians, you feel
in the moment, in the

217
00:10:02,570 --> 00:10:06,020
eyes of the conductor, if he
knows what he's saying.

218
00:10:06,020 --> 00:10:07,690
Oh, certainly.

219
00:10:07,690 --> 00:10:08,570
And that is something--

220
00:10:08,570 --> 00:10:10,690
They know that before he's
even done a beat.

221
00:10:10,690 --> 00:10:11,140
Exactly.

222
00:10:11,140 --> 00:10:12,860
By the time he comes in here
and walks along, yeah.

223
00:10:12,860 --> 00:10:15,080
You are like, hmm, no.

224
00:10:15,080 --> 00:10:17,900
And I know that because I
played in an orchestra.

00:21:32,580 --> 00:21:33,890
It's very important.

487
00:21:33,890 --> 00:21:36,150
And it's a symbol of future.

488
00:21:36,150 --> 00:21:38,790
Well, I'm glad all your fans
are going to be watching.

489
00:21:38,790 --> 00:21:40,590
Will little Martin be watching,
do you think?

490
00:21:40,590 --> 00:21:42,400
Absolutely.

491
00:21:42,400 --> 00:21:45,440
I wanted to ask you, does he
conduct his toys like you do?

492
00:21:45,440 --> 00:21:46,830
Well, he--

493
00:21:46,830 --> 00:21:47,495
I don't know.

494
00:21:47,495 --> 00:21:48,600
How old is he now, two?

495
00:21:48,600 --> 00:21:49,270
Almost two.

496
00:21:49,270 --> 00:21:49,520
Almost two.

497
00:21:49,520 --> 00:21:51,910
Almost two.

498
00:21:51,910 --> 00:21:54,736
In April 1st, he will be two.

499
00:21:54,736 --> 00:21:55,800
He's amazing.

500
00:21:55,800 --> 00:21:57,490
He's changed my life.

501
00:21:57,490 --> 00:22:06,180
And I hope for him to make the
best decisions in his life.

502
00:22:06,180 --> 00:22:09,670
If he's a musician, beautiful.

503
00:22:09,670 --> 00:22:11,290
Football player's
also good, eh?

504
00:22:11,290 --> 00:22:11,600
If he's a football--

505
00:22:11,600 --> 00:22:16,190
If he's a dancer like his
mother, it's great.

506
00:22:16,190 --> 00:22:19,490
If he's a lawyer, if
he's a shoemaker, I

507
00:22:19,490 --> 00:22:21,480
will be very happy.

508
00:22:21,480 --> 00:22:23,240
I would love for him to do--

509
00:22:23,240 --> 00:22:27,430
that he can see of what I do
that I do with love and with

510
00:22:27,430 --> 00:22:29,520
passion, and with the
commitment and with

511
00:22:29,520 --> 00:22:33,100
responsibility that you need to
have to do the things that

512
00:22:33,100 --> 00:22:39,696
you do, as Eloisa also do with
the things that she does.

513
00:22:39,696 --> 00:22:42,100
But if he's a conductor,
wonderful.

514
00:22:42,100 --> 00:22:44,330
So he's not conducting
his toys yet.

515
00:22:44,330 --> 00:22:47,040
But he'd probably conduct with
an iPhone rather than with a

516
00:22:47,040 --> 00:22:47,320
baton, I think.

517
00:22:47,320 --> 00:22:54,070
My grandmother gave him a car,
where you press a button, and

518
00:22:54,070 --> 00:22:57,950
it's coming some Bizet Carmen
music, and all of that.

519
00:22:57,950 --> 00:22:59,040
It's so funny.

520
00:22:59,040 --> 00:23:01,260
And he takes a baton.

521
00:23:01,260 --> 00:23:06,070
Since he was very small, he
was always taking this and

522
00:23:06,070 --> 00:23:06,590
doing this.

523
00:23:06,590 --> 00:23:07,090
The baton?

524
00:23:07,090 --> 00:23:07,880
Yes.

525
00:23:07,880 --> 00:23:11,440
And we built a paper
one because it was

526
00:23:11,440 --> 00:23:14,070
dangerous for him.

527
00:23:14,070 --> 00:23:16,220
And he was all the
time like that.

528
00:23:16,220 --> 00:23:17,070
It's beautiful.

529
00:23:17,070 --> 00:23:19,250
I feel very proud of that.

530
00:23:19,250 --> 00:23:23,260
But if he decides to do
whatever he wants,

531
00:23:23,260 --> 00:23:24,250
I will be so happy.

532
00:23:24,250 --> 00:23:28,010
Because I'm completely
in love.

533
00:23:28,010 --> 00:23:29,790
Completely.

534
00:23:29,790 --> 00:23:32,240
Well, I hope we see him soon
here in the Philharmonie.

535
00:23:32,240 --> 00:23:34,840
You have to bring him to a
children's concert, and we'll

536
00:23:34,840 --> 00:23:35,195
let him run around.

537
00:23:35,195 --> 00:23:36,740
He will be sitting there
on the stage.

538
00:23:36,740 --> 00:23:37,020
Very good.

539
00:23:37,020 --> 00:23:38,070
Gustavo, thank you so much.

540
00:23:38,070 --> 00:23:39,370
It's been a wonderful
week with you.

541
00:23:39,370 --> 00:23:41,420
Thank you so much.

542
00:23:41,420 --> 00:23:42,020
Thank you.

543
00:23:42,020 --> 00:23:42,920
Thank you.

544
00:23:42,920 --> 00:23:44,170
Bye.

545
00:23:44,170 --> 00:23:44,470

metadata.title: 古斯塔沃·杜达梅尔对话莎拉·维利斯
metadata.description: 2013年2月，委内瑞拉指挥家古斯塔沃·杜达梅尔指挥柏林爱乐乐团演绎了理查·施特劳斯的作品。在这段视频中，他于乐团的圆号演奏家莎拉·维利斯进行了一次对话。
